G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over the parties and the subject matter of custody and visitation pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, **G.L. c. 209C, § 20**, and applicable Massachusetts case law.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over the parties and the subject matter of custody and visitation pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, **G.L. c. 209C, § 20**, and applicable Massachusetts case law.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The “material and substantial change” and “best interests” tests have been established and reaffirmed in **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); and **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: This opinion is a custody case, but it does not discuss or apply a "material and substantial change" standard, nor does it frame its analysis in terms of the two-step "material and substantial change" then "best interests" test associated with modification of custody orders. The court focuses on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects on the child within the overarching best-interests analysis. Thus, while it discusses best interests and custody, it does not establish or reaffirm the specific "material and substantial change and best interests" tests as claimed.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The “material and substantial change” and “best interests” tests have been established and reaffirmed in **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); and **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman concerns the standard for removal of children from the Commonwealth where parents share joint legal and physical custody and interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30 in terms of a pure ‘best interests of the child’ analysis. It does not discuss or apply a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ test, nor does it purport to reaffirm a two‑step ‘material and substantial change’ plus ‘best interests’ framework used in post‑judgment custody modification cases such as Custody of Vaughn or Custody of Kali. Thus it cannot be cited as authority that those combined tests were “established and reaffirmed” in Mason itself.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents…shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth…without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The “material and substantial change” and “best interests” tests have been established and reaffirmed in **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); and **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: Custody of Kali is not a modification case and thus does not apply or reaffirm the separate “material and substantial change in circumstances” test for changing an existing custody order. Rather, it is an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and is focused on articulating and defending the “best interests of the child” standard and how statutory factors inform that inquiry. While Kali strongly reaffirms the best-interests test, it does not establish or reaffirm the material-and-substantial-change standard alongside it, so citing Kali for both tests together is inaccurate.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly … as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … This case raises the question of the relationship between the ‘best interests of the child’ standard set forth in the first paragraph of the statute and the three requirements set forth in the second. To resolve this question, we examine the origin of the ‘best interests of the child’ standard, whether that standard has been modified by the enactment of G. L. c. 209C, and the judge’s application of the standard in the present case.”

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: Courts must consider the stability and welfare of the child as paramount.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in removal disputes “the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern” and that the statutory phrase “upon cause shown” means removal must be in the best interests of the child. Its discussion of the ‘best interests’ analysis centers on the child’s quality of life, emotional, physical, and developmental needs, making clear that the stability and welfare of the child are the overriding consideration. Thus the case supports the proposition that courts must treat the child’s welfare as paramount.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “As most recently reformulated by the Supreme Court of New Jersey in Cooper v. Cooper, 99 N.J. 42 (1984), the ‘real advantage’ test is grounded on the ‘realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce . . . [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.’ Id. at 53. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern… The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.”}

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Courts must consider the stability and welfare of the child as paramount.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames custody and removal decisions around the child’s welfare and best interests, treating those considerations as the guiding and overriding principles. It quotes and applies prior Massachusetts authority that modifications must be based on whether a transfer of custody will be ‘conducive to the welfare of the child’ and that removal is permitted when in the ‘best interests of the child,’ thereby affirming that the child’s stability and welfare are paramount. The court reverses because the judge failed to give appropriate weight to these child-centered factors.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’… A parent’s request to relocate with a child from the Commonwealth must be ‘grounded on…[that] the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern….’”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: The Court may modify parenting plans upon finding that unforeseen changes render compliance impracticable or detrimental.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The concurrence addresses relocation and custody under the paternity statute, but it does not discuss a general standard for modifying parenting plans based on unforeseen changes making compliance impracticable or detrimental. Instead, it holds that the judge lacked authority to order the mother and child back to Massachusetts and emphasizes that the mother, as sole legal parent at the time of the move, was free to relocate. There is no articulated rule about post-judgment modification upon changed circumstances of the type described in the proposition.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: “The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. See ante at 550. As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is ‘free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].’ … After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart… and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a).”}

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: The Court may modify parenting plans upon finding that unforeseen changes render compliance impracticable or detrimental.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The case concerns a post‑divorce removal request and applies the Yannas ‘real advantage’/best interests framework, along with the statutory ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard for modification. It does not discuss modification based on parenting plans becoming impracticable or detrimental due to unforeseen changes; instead, it corrects the trial judge’s misapplication of what counts as a post‑judgment material change (the mother’s remarriage). Thus, the opinion does not establish or affirm the more general proposition that courts may modify parenting plans whenever unforeseen changes render compliance impracticable or detrimental.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28… (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

Bluhm v. Bluhm, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 122 (2.raw_text: Bluhm v. Bluhm, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 122 (2007)
Bluhm v. Bluhm, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 122 (2.proposition: Overnight work that interferes with a parent’s ability to provide safe, direct supervision is a recognized basis for modification.
Bluhm v. Bluhm, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 122 (2.case_name: Stagg Chevrolet, Inc. v. Board of Water Commissioners
Bluhm v. Bluhm, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 122 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion is a municipal tax/water charge abatement case and does not concern family law, parenting schedules, or modification of custody or parenting time. It addresses statutory notice requirements and appeal deadlines for water bill abatements, not overnight work or parental supervision. Therefore it cannot serve as authority for the claimed proposition about overnight work affecting a parent’s ability to provide safe, direct supervision as a basis for modification.
Bluhm v. Bluhm, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 122 (2.relevant_excerpt: "At issue is the legal effect of a notice that fails to include statutorily required information regarding the appellate process. We conclude that the Legislature mandated that this important information about how to appeal be included in the notice, and therefore the notice of the water commissioners’ decision was ineffective for the purpose of determining when to commence the running of the three-month appeal period. We therefore affirm the ATB decision awarding the abatement."

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Overnight work that interferes with a parent’s ability to provide safe, direct supervision is a recognized basis for modification.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rolde v. Rolde deals with initial custody and visitation determinations in a divorce and the division of marital assets; it does not involve a post‑judgment modification proceeding, nor does it discuss overnight work schedules or employment-related interference with a parent’s ability to supervise children as a basis for changing custody or visitation. There is no reference to overnight work, shift work, or similar facts, and thus the case cannot be read as recognizing such employment circumstances as a ground for modification.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “We pause merely to touch upon the husband’s claim that the judge ‘cut back so severely on the amount of time that [he] may spend with his children that it now is impossible for him to maintain a meaningful relationship with them.’ There is no error. From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order.”

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all custody matters in Massachusetts.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion applies a best-interests analysis in deciding whether to commit the children to the Department’s permanent custody, but it does not state that the “best interests of the child” standard governs all custody matters in Massachusetts. Instead, it frames the controlling standard in this context as clear and convincing proof of current parental unfitness, with best interests as part of that analysis. The case is thus authority for the role of best interests in care-and-protection/permanent custody decisions, not for a universal rule governing all custody matters statewide.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.relevant_excerpt: “A decision to remove children permanently from the home of their natural parents must be supported by clear and convincing evidence that the parents are currently unfit to care and provide for their children…. The judge could properly have concluded that committing the children to the custody of the department would be in their best interest.”

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all custody matters in Massachusetts.
